iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Reinforcing the Scaling Up of HIV Services: Strengthening HIV Prevention and Effective Targeting
iati-activity.description:
Ghana has a generalized HIV epidemic with pockets of high prevalence among most-at-risk populations, namely men having sex with men and their female partners, female sex workers, prison inmates, most-at-risk youth (15-24), workers (miners, uniformed services, transport workers), and vulnerable groups such as young boys and girls and female porters, as well as population in some geographic areas which are disproportionally affected by the epidemic. The prevalence rate has remained stable and below 5% over the past 16 years. The current national prevalence is 1.9% and prevalence among pregnant women is 2.6% (2007 sentinel surveillance report: National AIDS Control Program/Ghana Health Services).
This Program addresses gaps in the national response such as 1) superficial understanding of HIV in many segments of the population including youth, and an inability to move people from general knowledge and awareness of risk to actually adopting safer behaviors; 2) insufficient targeting of most-at-risk populations (MARPS) and vulnerable groups; 3) slow integration of HIV/AIDS and Sexual Reproductive Health (SRH); 4) shortfalls in institutional and community capacities to rapidly scale-up comprehensive HIV services.
Recognizing that clients of most-at-risk populations serve as a bridge between most-at-risk populations and general population in HIV transmission, this Program combines the targeting of interventions to MARPS and vulnerable groups and the targeting of the general population. As part of health system strengthening measures directly related to HIV services, this Program targets blood safety, Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT), early infant diagnosis, and integration of HIV and Sexually Transmitted Infections (STI) services.
As part of strengthening national health system in its response to HIV epidemic and emphasize the need of stronger partnerships between the public health sector, civil society and private sector, this Program will be implemented by multiple Principal Recipients: Ministry of Health/Ghana Health Services and Ghana AIDS Commission (public sector), Planned Parenthood Association of Ghana (civil society), Adventist Development and Relief Agency of Ghana (faith-based organization), and Ghana Employers’ Association (private sector) which will become Principal Recipient in Phase 2 of the Program.

iati-activity.title: Ghana - Accelerating access to prevention, care, support and treatment of all persons affected by HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. (HIV/AIDS Component)
iati-activity.description: The overall goal of the program supported by this grant is to increase access and generate greater demand for both prevention and care services for groups vulnerable to HIV infection, and to improve care and support for those already living with the virus. The program is targeting youth, pregnant women, newborn babies, and people living with HIV and AIDS in specific areas of the country. To achieve its goal, the program is increasing the availability of voluntary counseling and testing services; expanding the availability of services for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV; establishing comprehensive care for people living with HIV and AIDS, including antiretroviral treatment and treatment for opportunistic infections; and training and deploying National Service Personnel in 15 districts of the country’s Eastern Region so that the country’s district-level response initiative can be expanded into communities of people living with HIV and AIDS.

iati-activity.title: Ghana - Accelerating access to prevention, care, support and treatment of all persons affected by HIV/AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria. (HIV/AIDS Component)
iati-activity.description: In Ghana, TB patients have problems accessing TB services for a variety of reasons that include low service coverage, poverty and ignorance. The program supported by this grant has an overall goal of promoting equitable access to prevention, care, support and treatment for all affected by TB through strengthened partnerships between government, civil society and the private sector. The program targets people living with TB, disadvantaged poor individuals, pregnant women, and children under age five. To achieve its goals, the program is conducting DOTS training at 60 private sector diagnostic and treatment centers; administering an incentives package aimed at increasing participation of private health service providers; renovating DOTS treatment centers; and conducting at least 2,800 home visits to reduce the rate of treatment defaults.

iati-activity.title: Accelerating Access to Prevention, Treatment, and Care and Support for Malaria and Achieving the Millennium Goals
iati-activity.description: Malaria is hyper-endemic in Ghana, accounting for 44.5 percent of outpatient illnesses, 36.9 percent of hospital admissions and 13.2 percent of deaths. Its greatest impact is on children under age five and pregnant women. The program supported by this grant is expanding existing activities, with the goal of reducing malaria-specific illness and death by 25 percent through improvements in access to prevention and treatment of malaria and strengthened partnerships among the government, civil society and private sector. The program targets children under age five and pregnant women. To achieve its goal the program is training home caregivers so that they can respond appropriately and immediately at the onset of the disease; providing insecticide-treated bed nets to households with children under age five and pregnant women; providing intermittent preventative treatment for pregnant women; providing artemisinin-based combination therapy for effective treatment of the disease; and educating health workers on the recently adopted national policy for using artemisinin-based combination therapy as the first line of treatment.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Reinforcing the Scaling Up of HIV Services: Strengthening HIV Prevention and Effective Targeting
iati-activity.description:
Ghana has a generalized HIV epidemic with pockets of high prevalence among most-at-risk populations, namely men having sex with men and their female partners, female sex workers, prison inmates, most-at-risk youth (15-24), workers (miners, uniformed services, transport workers), and vulnerable groups such as young boys and girls and female porters, as well as population in some geographic areas which are disproportionally affected by the epidemic. The prevalence rate has remained stable and below 5% over the past 16 years. The current national prevalence is 1.9% and prevalence among pregnant women is 2.6% (2007 sentinel surveillance report: National AIDS Control Program/Ghana Health Services).
This Program addresses gaps in the national response such as 1) superficial understanding of HIV in many segments of the population including youth, and an inability to move people from general knowledge and awareness of risk to actually adopting safer behaviors; 2) insufficient targeting of most-at-risk populations (MARPS) and vulnerable groups; 3) slow integration of HIV/AIDS and Sexual Reproductive Health (SRH); 4) shortfalls in institutional and community capacities to rapidly scale-up comprehensive HIV services.
Recognizing that clients of most-at-risk populations serve as a bridge between most-at-risk populations and general population in HIV transmission, this Program combines the targeting of interventions to MARPS and vulnerable groups and the targeting of the general population. As part of health system strengthening measures directly related to HIV services, this Program targets blood safety, Prevention of Mother-to-Child Transmission (PMTCT), early infant diagnosis, and integration of HIV and Sexually Transmitted Infections (STI) services.
As part of strengthening national health system in its response to HIV epidemic and emphasize the need of stronger partnerships between the public health sector, civil society and private sector, this Program will be implemented by multiple Principal Recipients: Ministry of Health/Ghana Health Services and Ghana AIDS Commission (public sector), Planned Parenthood Association of Ghana (civil society), Adventist Development and Relief Agency of Ghana (faith-based organization), and Ghana Employers’ Association (private sector) which will become Principal Recipient in Phase 2 of the Program.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Accelerating Access to Prevention and Treatment of Malaria through Scaling-Up of Home-Based Care and Indoor Residual Spraying towards the Achievement of the National Strategic Goal
iati-activity.description:
1. Background and Summary: Malaria is endemic in all parts of Ghana and puts its population of 22.4 million at risk of malaria throughout the year. Over the past five years, between 3.1 and 3.5 million cases of clinical malaria were reported in public health facilities each year. Malaria accounts for 37.5% of all outpatient illnesses, 36% of admissions and 33.4% of all deaths in children under five years and 9.4% of deaths among pregnant women.
The Program supplements the program supported through the fourth Round of Global Fund financing by focusing on two main interventions: 1) scaling up home based care in 123 rural districts to ensure that parents and caretakers recognize symptoms and signs of malaria and respond appropriately and promptly by seeking treatment from trained Community Drug Distributors; and 2) scale-up indoor residual spraying in 40 districts with the highest malaria burden. Universal coverage of bed nets is covered through the RCC program. Activities related to the universal coverage of bed nets are funded through the Global Fund grant number GHN-405-G04-M.
In line with goals of global malaria control initiatives and the National Malaria Control Strategic Plan, this Program aims at contributing to the attainment of higher percentages of population in 40 targeted districts to be protected by indoor residual spraying, and a high percentage of children under five with malaria/fever receiving appropriate treatment at community level within 24 hours of fever onset.
The Ministry of Health of the Government of the Republic of Ghana will implement the Home-Based Care (HBC) component, while AGAMC will implement the component of Indoor Residual Spraying (IRS). Both AGAMC and the Ministry of Health will conduct health care and community capacity building, monitoring and evaluation, operational research, and behavior change communication in their respective areas.
Implementation of Indoor Residual Spraying will be based on the experience and best practices of AGA who has been implementing an IRS program in the Obuasi mining community since 2005. Results to date in Obuasi show over 74% reduction in malaria cases following two years of operation according to AGA’s data sources.
As of the effective date of this Agreement, the Program has two Principal Recipients who are jointly and severally responsible for all obligations of the Principal recipient under this Agreement, AngloGold Ashanti (Ghana) Limited ("AGA") and AngloGold Ashanti (Ghana) Malaria Control Limited ("AGAMC"). AGAMC shall be responsible for all aspects of the programmatic and financial management of the Program and AGA undertakes to indemnify the Global Fund and make good on the Principal Recipient’s obligation in case of default by the AGAMC under this Grant Agreement.

iati-activity.description: The goal of the program supported by this grant is to decrease HIV and AIDS-related illness and death through a comprehensive package of prevention, treatment, care and support services and integration of HIV and AIDS and TB activities. The program also targets patients with advanced HIV disease who are in need of treatment and HIV/TB co-infected patients.

iati-activity.description: A baseline study carried out by UNAIDS shows that HIV and AIDS prevalence rates at each of the eight borders of the corridor were at least double that of the corresponding country figures. The program supported by this grant intends to target populations that are in constant movement by providing additional HIV and AIDS services for people living with and affected by the disease at the eight borders and delineated hot spots. Grant funds will be used to implement regional information, education and communication and behavior change communication strategies; conduct regional social marketing of male and female condoms; promote syndromatic management of sexually transmitted infections; and provide voluntary counseling and testing and prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV services. The program targets long distance drivers, sex workers and their clients, uniform personnel working at the borders, people living with HIV, youth, traders, hawkers, HIV positive women and women of child-bearing age, children born to HIV positive mothers and orphans.

iati-activity.reporting-org: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
iati-activity.title: Accelerating access to prevention, care, support and treatment of malaria for targeted persons in 20 districts
iati-activity.description: Malaria is hyper-endemic in Ghana, accounting for 44.5 percent of outpatient illnesses, 36.9 percent of hospital admissions and 13.2 percent of deaths. Its greatest impact is on children under age five and pregnant women. The overall goal of the program supported by this grant is to reduce malaria-related illness in children under age five and pregnant women in 20 selected districts through the promotion of access to prevention and treatment of malaria and strengthened partnerships between government, civil society and the private sector. To achieve its goal, the program is providing intermittent presumptive treatment to pregnant women, increasing the usage of insecticide-treated bed nets in households with children under age five and pregnant women, and increasing the proportion of mother/caregivers who are able to identify early symptoms of uncomplicated and severe malaria and seek prompt treatment.

conditions.condition: b. The delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of a revised budget for the Program Term (the "Revised Program Budget") if the amendments incorporated into the Updated M&E Plan require consequential amendments to be made to the budget for the Program Term that was approved by the Global Fund as of the effective date of this Agreement; and
c. The written approval of the Global Fund of the Updated M&E Plan and Revised Program Budget (the latter only being applicable if condition b. of this sub-section B.4 is applicable).

b. The delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of a revised budget for the Program Term (the "Revised Budget") if the development of the PSM Plan listed in condition a. of this Sub-section B.6 results in amendment to the Program budget as approved at the time of the effective date of this Agreement;

c. The PSM Plan shall include a specific outline for the logistics management of MDR-TB drugs covering their receipt, storage and distribution at various levels of the health system. It shall adequately address scale-up of supplies and security of the commodities;

d. The written approval of the Global Fund of the PSM Plan and the Revised Budget. The Principal Recipient understands and agrees that all subsequent changes made to the PSM Plan, including without limitation, all work plans, budgets and performance frameworks, shall be resubmitted to the Global Fund for its written approval. The Principal Recipient also acknowledges that any savings identified shall be de-committed from the amount of Grant funds listed in Block 8 of the Face Sheet of this Agreement or reprogrammed, at the discretion of the Global Fund and subject to appropriate justifications being provided by the Principal Recipient and the Ghana CCM; and

Conditions Precedent to Second Disbursement (Terminal Date as stated in block 7F of the Face Sheet)
The second disbursement of Grant funds by the Global Fund to the Principal Recipient shall be subject to each of the following conditions being met in form and substance satisfactory to the Global Fund:
a. Delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of the terms of the Incentives Scheme, demonstrating the link between the payment of incentives, salary top-ups or other performance bonuses payable to all employees or consultants of the Principal Recipient ("Incentives") and Program performance, identifying the persons eligible for such Incentives, and demonstrating that there is no duplication of the scope of work or responsibilities between the terms of employment and the scope of work of existing employment positions and any new scope of work or responsibilities funded by Grant funds; and b. Delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of written endorsement by the Ghana CCM of the Incentives scheme.

SPECIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS
The Principal Recipient shall cooperate with the relevant office of the Green Light Committee (the "GLC") in the GLC’s efforts to provide support to the Principal Recipient with respect to the implementation, management and monitoring of the MDR-TB-related services provided in-country and any needed scale-up of such services. Accordingly, the Principal Recipient shall budget and authorize the Global Fund to disburse up to a maximum of US$ 50,000, or a lower amount as agreed with GLC and the Global Fund, each year to pay for GLC services.

SPECIAL TERMS AND CONDITIONS The Principal Recipient shall ensure that the internal auditor shall submit each bi-annual internal audit report, simultaneously, to the ARIC, Ghana CCM, and the Global Fund. The action plan and the status on the implementation of any internal audit recommendations shall be submitted by the Principal Recipient with its regular progress and disbursement update reports.

The first disbursement of Grant funds by the Global Fund to the Principal Recipient is subject to the satisfaction of each of the following conditions:
a. the delivery by the Principal Recipient to the Global Fund of a statement confirming the bank account into which the Grant funds will be disbursed as indicated in block 10 of the face sheet of this Agreement;

The disbursement of Grant funds by the Principal Recipient to finance Program activities implemented by the Ministry of Defense, Ministry of Transport and Communication and the Red Cross Society of Eritrea, is subject to the following conditions:
b. The written approval of the Global Fund of the compliance with this condition
